message.content:
cs.CV, cs.LG, cs.MM, cs.AI, cs.NE 

This paper proposes a method for video classification that focuses on appearance and motion features. It specifically addresses the computational expense of extracting optical flow features and proposes a solution that hallucinates these features from appearance features. Therefore, the paper is likely to belong to the computer vision (cs.CV) sub-category. Additionally, the proposed method involves modeling temporal and contextual relationships, which suggests that it may also belong to the machine learning (cs.LG) and multimedia (cs.MM) sub-categories. The paper also involves neural networks, which suggests that it may belong to the artificial intelligence (cs.AI) sub-category. Finally, the paper involves optimization and efficiency, which suggests that it may also belong to the neural and evolutionary computing (cs.NE) sub-category.
